commentBody:
A very pleasant puzzle, 
but to me it felt like an easy Friday.

The entries were fun; maybe kick the cluing up a notch. 
Or two notches? 
I WANT TO TRY something tougher.

Thanks, Sarah and Rafa.

Stats initially glitched to give me a 5:36‚Äîwhile it was on the easier end, it was quite that quick for me in reality! Some fun bits, but I was really hoping 2D would be DREAM to intersect 15A‚Äôs DREAMYOGA.
I liked this puzzle. Some good crunchy clues, some fresh fill, smooth overall.
That was quick and painless.
27A/27D was a definite natick for me: MOCHI/MOOD?
I done did this puzz

*checks yes, adds smiley, passes note back*

Fun and smooth. A few misses -- SEIzeS before SEISMS, dine before GNAW, TEen before TEMP, DRoss before DRECK, thought about TigER for 50A, might have considered durian for 25D except I knew 40A, and really wanted  54A to be "crowd surf" -- but easily fixed. 

WANTTOTRY DREAMYOGA? I vote YEA...

BEST ACTOR, haha!

Lewis, what say you?
I find it quite fun that Madam Edebiri shows up in both themeless puzzle for this week. Im not surprised she has shown up 4 times this year alone!
Not Saturday difficult - not even close.
One Hamilton mention and now I‚Äôm listening to the entire soundtrack once again lol. Had to check if NEVIS got a name drop. I guess I‚Äôll have to listen to the whole thing just to make sure. üòå

Crowd Surf and Smokey Eye before STAGE DIVE and SLEEP MASK in the SE corner made things difficult there until they were forced out by the Downs.  
An amusing, lively puzzle, not unexpected from these two constructors, but, as others have noted, not Saturday tough.

Interesting how we have AYO again after the whole name was there yesterday.

And we have YEA again, with its more common meaning of "affirmative vote".

Caitlin quotes what Adlai Stevenson may have said, but he  also memorably said, as I recall: ‚ÄúEggheads of the world unite; you have nothing to lose but your yokes.‚Äù  I‚Äôm glad I got some current slang , but still no real idea who Ayo Edebiri is.
I too would prefer a harder Saturday. Puzzle, that is.
I've never heard of "connect the dots" referred to as "dot to dot". Is this regional? I grew up in New Jersey.

For some reason, EDWIN - although on the tip of my metaphorical tongue - wouldn't bubble to the surface of my brain. That, along with never having heard of DREAM YOGA, slowed me down quite a bit. (But at least I remembered AYO from yesterday)!

In the end, it was a typo that cost me the last 5 minutes of the solve. I thought I had the puzzle done, but no happy gold star appeared. I felt the Japanese dessert should be MOCHI, but it was a guess, 
and MOOD just didn't resonate, so I tried a bunch of guesses for the crossing letter. (Dood? Good? Hood? Food? Tood? Wood? All seemed equally likely modern slang, and what do I know about Japanese cuisine? But no).

Finally decided to go through everything else, only to find that I had a typo in 1A. I must have had the cursor on the wrong square at some point when I typed an O, because it read EGGHEADEo. Fixed that, went back to 27A to revert to M, and finally got the happy news. 

Even with all that, the app said my time was a little over half my average, so I guess it rates as pretty easy.

One of those puzzles where you step over the obvious to find the skewed, but if you do it every time you miss the junk (boat, that is), and sometimes have to take a step back, in a different direction.  The fills were not difficult, but the cluing was sly, and it was like learning to dance with a new partner (two partners, this time).  DAY SPA was an obvious destination, but I wanted to body surf, and a private detective as an eye shadow for a night out (don't ask my why about that one).  

The puzzle put me in a very good MOOD, and I thank you for that, Sarah and Rafael.  Let's do it again.

I LOVED this puzzle! It wasn't as easy for me as for some of you, but I did solve it more quickly than most Saturdays. 

Just like Deb, I was so proud of myself for entering yoganidra for 15A with no crosses. Eventually, I realized YOGA was the last four letters so grudgingly changed it to nidraYOGA. But 5D had to be EMTS, so I changed it to DREAM, muttering the whole time, "That's not what it's called." Then, just like Deb, finished the puzzle and Googled "Is dream yoga the same as yoga nidra?" and learned exactly what Deb learned. Nope. It's a different thing.

THIS IS WHY YOU DON'T COMPLAIN IN THE COMMENTS ABOUT AN ANSWER BEING WRONG WITHOUT FIRST LOOKING IT UP! 

But now that I know what it is, I want to start practicing it! I already lucid dream occasionally, which is just so much fun because as soon as you realize you're asleep and dreaming, you also realize that you can do anything you want. Sure, you can fly or walk through walls. At a piano recital and forgot to practice? You can play anything you can think of. On stage and forgot your lines? No problem. You can make up the lines because none of it's real!

There were so many other fun answers that were totally on my wavelength. I got AIRSIGN right away because I've also wondered why Aquarius isn't a water sign. Great clue. Got SLEEPMASK because I wear one every night so that, as a night owl and LATERISER, I don't get awakened early by the sun.
As soon as ‚Äúbottled spirit‚Äù solved to GENIE, I knew this would be a killer grid and I was not disappointed. Maybe the best set of clues so far this year.
Any other night owls and late risers here??

This has been a great week for Crosswords. I fell in love with Thursday's and had a blast with Friday's. They just progressively got better each day. Today's was better than most Saturdays. It was easier than most, but challenging in a good way. Not filled with archaic words and convoluted clues. Bottled spirit and Shakes not sundaes made me smile. The Washington clue sent me down a rabbit hole until I had enough of a few crosses to see "actor", I already had the B. So it wasn't old George after all. TIL a new word DRECK. After filling it in, I had to look it up. I'd never heard it before. So, congratulations this weeks constructors and Mr. Shortz for a fun week of NYT Crosswords. See ya Sunday. Cheers y'all from TEXAS.

Well that was fun and fast! This night owl should probably head down sometime soon because I have things to do tomorrow and I can't be too much of a LATERISER, but I wanted to mention how exciting it was to have The Mousetrap in a clue at 14D when -  literally - immediately before I started the puzzle, I purchased tickets to The Mousetrap at the Guthrie!  MOOD! (Just kidding, I have no idea how to use that slang term. Usually when I'm in a MOOD it's not really relatable or good...  hahaha)

Also, regarding the hauntingly beautiful Wreck of the Edmund Fitzgerald, if you are a Severance watcher, I'm wondering what the heck is with that song in the soundtrack. If anyone answers on that, please don't do any spoilers for anyone who hasn't watched the show yet. I don't think my comment is a spoiler, it's just a tune that has shown up and surprised me. 

My fifth grade music teacher had us sing that song at a concert.... that and Dust in the Wind by Kansas.  Thinking back, it seems a little dark for a bunch of fifth graders to be singing both of those songs, but you know it gave me an early respect for the songs and I'm here for it!  Never been much for traditional anyhow...  I was always going to turn out a little bit dark.

Several really fun clues, but it went pretty fast for me for a Saturday. I enjoyed it though!
Isn't "fortunetelling" supposed to be hyphenated?
18 across threw me off quite a bit. Shouldn't the clue read "Fruits" instead of "Fruit"?
Is AYO the new ONO?
It's been a while since i've enjoyed a clue as much as "Bottled spirits." Thank you!

A very wistful solve for an insomniac, what with SLEEP MASKs, LATE RISing, and DREAM YOGA. Like Caitlin, I thought the latter was going to be yoga nidra, although I‚Äôve heard of the Tibetan practice of dream yoga. I‚Äôve been a kundalini practitioner since college, and my most memorable teacher tried to initiate me into some Tibetan rites but, to dream, one has to sleep first and, well, the latter has always been problematic for me. 

MOOD as clued crossed with MOCHI led to my having to leave the M square empty till I completed the remaining grid, then running the alphabet. There are two assumptions which come shining through in how both the NYT crossword puzzles and Spelling Bee are edited: (1) modern slang is ubiquitous and/or worth acquiring, and (2) everyone is or should be a foodie. I‚Äôd argue this is more of a culture-creating than culture-reflecting position, but I‚Äôd be a pretty lone voice. 

Aron for ADAM held me up for a couple of minutes and briefly left me wondering why East of Eden would be clued as a movie instead of one of the finest example of our American literature. But then Virginia (or perhaps Leonard?) WOOLF came and went without a single work being cited. And so, true to form, the puzzle managed to avoid requiring the solver to have ever read anything resembling literature (with apologies to Emily TESH, but still). 

I liked the puzzle, by the way. I suspect the dumbed-down clueing is on the editors, not the constructors. 

Have a good Saturday, everyone.
Is the ‚ÄúWashington‚Äù in the clue for 31 down Denzel? Or am I missing something?

Finished in 17 mins which is apparently 37 mins quicker than my average, whereas yesterday was way slower than normal. Definitely feel like Fri and sat were the wrong way round this week, but I guess it's different for everyone. Nice puzzle nonetheless with DRECK being the only dreck

Had a moment of frustration at 20D where I could remember the title of the book but not the author! Then it clicked‚Äîmorning brain, what can I say... Delighted to see TESH's Some Desperate Glory get all the attention it deserves, even in an unexpected venue!

I, um, did the Saturday puzzle by mistake! That is, early. I usually do my crosswords in the evening, and I picked this one up a little on the later side. I was so pleased to have done a Friday without turning on autocheck, but I was super confused when I went to read Wordplay and landed on the column for the Saturday puzzle. Whoa! Usually Saturday stumps me. As a bonus, now I still have the Friday puzzle to do. 

I liked this one and was happy to see my old pal Virginia WOOLF make an appearance.
Ayo as an answer again?   That‚Äôs what, three days in a row?  That‚Äôs way too much for an actress you have to be a fan of a particular show to know.

I thought yesterday had hit new low. Nope today was worse. Not only full of pop culture trivia but the clues to the rest often are a stretch or just make no sense.
Please hire some editors with common sense. Making puzzles obscure isn't good puzzle making. Even if you can't work it out you should be left with satisfaction at the cleverness.

Hoping for a good Sunday.
57A clue brought to mind the great Billie Holiday lilting‚Ä¶ üéµ The difficult I‚Äôll do right now, the impossible will take a little while üéµ‚Ä¶

Memorable moments:
‚Ä¢	Stopping after filling in MOOD, trying it out in the "That's relatable" sense, finding it perfect, and wowing over how beautifully our language evolves.
‚Ä¢	Going ‚ÄúHuh!‚Äù at realizing that ERROL backward spells another icon of old Hollywood.
‚Ä¢	That thrill when my brain slipped me the answer unlocking an impenetrable spot.
‚Ä¢	Going ‚ÄúWow!‚Äù and ‚ÄúHah!‚Äù at those stellar clues for SLEEP MASK, BEST ACTOR, GENIE, HAIL MARY, and especially [They‚Äôre grated outdoors] for DRAINS.
‚Ä¢	Melting at beauty upon uncovering MAKE MAGIC, ROYAL WE, and DEEP FAKE.
‚Ä¢	Meditating for a moment on the wise and exquisitely expressed Santayana quote.
‚Ä¢	Surge of respect as I take in the completed grid, with its measly 68 words and 32 blocks, and find it free of DRECK and abounding with longs (15), not one of them boring.

Sarah and Rafael, you filled me with richness today.  This was far sweeter than simply a fill-iin-the-squares.  Thank you!
Fun, quite easy for a Saturday.....

Can a Genie fit in a gravy boat?
Asking for a friend.

A fun puzzle, with lots of easy, a few hard.

Didn't find this one unusually easy - typical tough Saturday workout for me, and had to look up more than a couple of things, but ended up being an enjoyable solve. 

RE: 34 down - was living in Upper Michigan when that happened. Now I have the lyrics of the last verse of the song stuck in my head. And...

...yep - GITCHEGUMEE was an answer in a puzzle once. 

And of course I have some puzzle finds - I'll put those in replies. 

...
Sundaes is more burying the lead on shakes completely than a misdirect. True Saturday clue. Is a vote for not in more common use as Aye?

Beautiful puzzle. 
Under 70 words? That‚Äôs so tough to do.

Maybe not tough to construct,
but is MAKING MAGIC when you
can do it this well.

Wow.

Color CC impressed!
Thank you!
For ‚ÄúRely on audience support during a show,‚Äù I was so proud to immediately come up with CROWD SURF. Too bad it was wrong‚Ä¶

Marshalled more grey cells in the SE corner than the rest of the puzzle combined.  Nicely done. 

I checked "Yes".

Day 357 - quick one.  Below 50% of avg Saturday, Thursday still my slowest day this week.  No idea what MOOD means in this context though.  Is it a noun?  Adjective?  Did Crossfire introduce an Urban Dictionary add-in or something?

Question: Isn‚Äôt it always cheating just a tiny bit to solve using the app, because if you fill in all the squares but hear no music you get a mulligan of sorts? Today was my fastest Saturday ever, out of perhaps 300, but I was wrong in the first letter of 27A and D. There was even a bit of trial and error in fixing the mistake, working off the theory that the slang term would be a repurposing of an actual English word and the initial letter of the snack would be one that can begin a Japanese syllable. So hurrah! I heard the music and I got my record. But had I, for example, done the puzzle in an in-flight magazine, the next passenger, perhaps someone Japanese, might have glanced disappointedly at the already completed puzzle and thought, ‚ÄúThat goofball didn‚Äôt even know what mochi is.‚Äù Of course the object of the game is fun and however one solves is fine, but can I really pat myself on the back without embarrassment?

Today was not easy for me (at all). FIEF (although so obvious and straightforward in hindsight), SEISMS, and the whole SE corner took me longer than I care to admit. I broke in with SLEEPMASK but every other letter felt like an eternity. Happy music felt like MAKING MAGIC today! 

I'm usually fast with Musa's puzzles but not today.

In other fun news, I am running for local political office in my lovely Town of Millton (Board of Assessors) and I'm off to go hold my sign in the rain. Election is April 29.

Local government in northeastern towns is fascinating. For a fun rabbit hole, google the concept of Town Meeting. Such a wild form of democracy that was completely foreign to me when I moved from Cleveland 20+ years ago. We take our local elections extremely seriously here, as I think it should be. 

Cheers!

This one defeated me. Didn't know MOCHI or MOOD (as clued), so I was "naticked" there. Other than that, another puzzle that seemed too easy to run on a Saturday. Themeless Wednesday again. Finished in less than 20 minutes, and I'm hardly a speed-solver.

"Artery access point" for ONRAMP was clever, as was "Bottled spirit" for GENIE.

That said, "Source of an unsigned love letter" for SECRETADMIRER is simply much too direct for a Saturday clue. Even "Pronoun also known as pluralis majestatis" was a giveaway, and I've never seen the Latin name before. As was "Lake ___, setting for "The Wreck of the Edmund Fitzgerald" for SUPERIOR. Surely, on Saturday, more obfuscation than this is possible. 

A nicely made puzzle. all in all. Too many phrases and names for my liking. I miss seeing interesting *words* rather than stuff like WANTTOTRY and ONEPAGER. If stuff like this is being stacked, maybe stacking contributes more to the constructor than it does to the solvers? 

Will need to add MOCHI to my knowledge base. Think I'll pass on MOOD as clued.
Not gonna lie, today was a hard puzzle especially the southeast. Really liked the clues for HAILMARY and SLEEPMASK.

Fun puzzle!

I guess "same" and "mood" are same same but different?

I often don't look for or notice constructors' names before I start a puzzle, and today was no exception.  As I was working this one, I started getting excited by the thought that a possibly new constructor was involved in making this fresh, fun, fast puzzle that was right in my wheelhouse.  But, it was Rafa and Sarah - not disappointed, but not surprised.  Even the constructors' note was interesting and fun to read - with a tie-in picture, no less.  Thanks to you both for this Saturday with real personality.

Sorry, I‚Äôm not up on modern slang. It irks me when the meanings of words change and no one sent me the memo.  And then I require an explanation and get an eye roll of contempt.  
  I‚Äôm also not a fan of that phrase every one uses all the time, ‚Äú hear me out‚Äù.

Nice Goldilocks puzzle for me, neither too easy nor too hard (for a Saturday).  Just right!

Too much of AYO Edebiri?  Not yet. She's becoming a gimme, though.  And I appreciate not needing to spell her last name, although I think I have it down now.

Now that I think about it, though, it seems to me that the puzzle was both too easy and too hard: a surprising number of gimmes for a Saturday, and some real head scratchers to balance it out.

This was interesting for the clever clues, but....  well, I posted (below) about that.
Just wanted to say it was a neat puzzle for the most part....and I'm glad I got all of the obscure, twisty entries.  WOOF!
STAGE DIVE?

Aron before ADAM.
Home....field? Court?  
PETAL for fortune-telling?  Oh, good grief. Anyone still doing that?  Probably works as well as any other method of finding a mate....  Onward...

When I was maybe eight years old, I became obsessed with The Wreck of the Edmund Fitzgerald, and would listen to it over and over on my Walkman. Now that I'm older, though, I recognize the Madeira as being a way cooler shipwreck. https://greatlakesdrive.com/GLD/property/madeira-schooner-barge-1900-1905/

Yes, we liked your puzzle!
44D is appreciated, most of us probably thought Apple before AMIGA - had a work friend who liked to look over at my screen and say, "my Amiga at home can do that"; until of course I investigated Amiga and thought about programming for it...  
Thanks for jogging my memory

By a subtle twist of fate, I was perusing the menu of a poke joint last night, as I'm picking up lunch there on the way to Mom's house. That was the first time I'd encountered MOCHI, and today was the second. That's a good thing, too, because MOOD was a complete mystery. Anyway, I blazed through this puzzle in just over 15 minutes, despite not knowing the sci-fi author or the ceramics maker. Way too easy.

Regarding the column photo; OPTIMUS Prime is not a fire truck, he is a semi truck with a red cab and a blue-and-silver trailer. And it's not a "disguise," it's a costume, hence the term cosplay. Do some research.
BONMOT, BESTACTOR, TAM, TESH, MOCHI, FIEF. that's all im going to say

(Third attempt.  I switched the actual word of 46D out in case that's the reason...)


 Some random thoughts. None meant to be a criticism of the puzzle. 

AYO is back again. Three times since Tuesday. 

YEA is back again, but with its better-known meaning, an affirmative vote. 

Do Bill NYE's fans actually count down to the start of his shows? 

Is the opposite of YEA GNAW? 

Vulgarity alert: At least in its original Yiddish, 46D means more than junk. At least it did to my Yiddish-speaking grandmother. 

Kudos to whoever came up with the clue for 31D. 

Fastest Saturday for me in a few months. Last one that was faster was 2/1.

This one just sort of intuited itself into completion. Get an across, get a down...
Wow - could 46D really be DRECK!? Liked that.
Knew neither _OOD (my granddaughter hasn't used that one) or _OCHI, so had to run the letters. 
Annnd...here I am on a rainy Saturday. Time to clean house.

"I could go for some grass right now."

Cow *mooed*


I liked it. 


Why did the chicken cross the road?

To see where the egg headed.

I remember feeling "hip" when I learned the phrase "I feel ya." from the Idris Elba character on "The Wire".  And it shocks me that that was over 20 years ago.

And now I've got to learn "MOOD"???

Great fun. Only stumbling block was MOCHI and MOOD. Mochi I should have known. Mood I would never have known, though perhaps I should have asked my daughter, her being in the neighboring room and always pleased when Dad gets shown up.
I got mood immediately. seems like a lot of people had a hard time with that one..  goes to show how different ages may know certain terms lol
I liked it! I do not mind millennialese in my puzzles, just as I do not mind classic literature or opera clues! Fun sat, though I came in wayyy under my average
Fast and fun

Kudos, really enjoyed this puzzle! Great long entries, neat clueing and few obscurities. 
Whenever puzzles like 4/16 or 3/10 make me want to drop everything and cancel my subscription, I think of puzzles like these to keep me going.

AMIGA is a good answer. (Even if it's a "brand" in the "iMac" sense not in the "Apple" sense)

But I think the Wordplay column is conflating two phenomena.

The Amiga itself is not very obscure, particularly for any fan of video games, and even moreso outside of the USA. It was commercially relevant well into 90s, and there were usually still Amiga versions of big computer games, and they were often still the definitive versions even then.

But the subject of the linked article is about the emulation scene, and largely about the bizarre phenomenon of the operating system AmigaOS still being updated to this day. Which is only for the truest of true sickos.
I love Ayo Edebiri and I love The Bear. But does she really have to be in every other puzzle? Great puzzle otherwise!
Brilliant misdirects! I can‚Äôt be the only one who had ‚ÄúDROSS‚Äù instead of ‚ÄúDRECK‚Äù and ‚ÄúABEL‚Äù instead of ‚ÄúADAM‚Äù in the bottom right corner. Fun to work it out!

One of the joys of spending New Years in rural Japan is making mochi by hand outdoors. It‚Äôs a bit terrifying, because you swing a large mallet at the pile of sweet rice that is placed in the hollow of a tree stump, and in between each swing of the mallet, the proprietress of the inn will swoop in and quickly knead the mochi.

It‚Äôs not sporting to pause for her‚Äîyou‚Äôre just supposed to establish a rhythm in swinging the mallet and hope that you don‚Äôt smash her hands instead of the mochi.

When finished, the mochi cakes are wrapped in nori (sushi seaweed) and baked on top of the wood stove. Yum!

Faster than average, but not by much. Having owned a couple Atari computers (as tricked out as they could be, back then), I was stuck there for quite a bit. I finally figured out ADAM (unfamiliar with anything but the title, but the answer was obvious once I thought about it for a second), and that led to other things that ruled out Atari (STILL the best keyboard I've used, other than the IBM Selectric).

This was a very fast Saturday for me. I choose to think it's because I'm EGGHEADED, but the more likely reason is the coffee and Long John I had while doing it. I had APPLE, then ATARI, before hitting on AMIGA, which made me think of my job testing computer games in the 1980s. The Amigas were like computers from the future. They were so far ahead of other home computers of the day, especially graphically. And they displayed a cryptic "Guru meditation" error when they crashed, which was sort of cool but happened far too often. Thanks for the fun!

Hey, why is the "Email me..." checkbox always checked by default now on the Android app? It's annoying.
These Saturday puzzles are getting easier and easier. When I go to the archives, even 10 years ago they are far more challenging.

Very enjoyable.
Some culture clashes:
IVIES obviously
SEISMS not in common use
ON RAMP = slip road
TEAR in this sense = binge, bender, splurge, spree
LIT ON = alight upon
YEA = aye (eg the ayes have it in Parliament)
TAM = in Scotland usually tammie
NYE = in Scotland - Hogmanay
HARD PASS - not in common use

Will I remember MOOD? I don't even use "That's so relatable" so probably not!
I really enjoyed this puzzle.  Not too fast for me !  Thanks!
This was the perfect amount of crunchiness for my skill level. The fruit plural for DATES (correctly) tripped me up more than I‚Äôd like to admit.

Thought I was going to finish under a quarter of an hour, way faster than I like, but fortunately did not know the Hugo award author or the modern slang and also had the wrong computer (Atari, then Apple). So those two spots provided an extra 5 minutes of fun.

Thank you Sarah and Rafael! It's a YES from me.

This was quite challenging for me. A very ‚Äòuncomfortable‚Äô solve. But I got through it pretty quickly. 

 I don‚Äôt think I even had five entries last night, falling asleep while trying to solve. Which unfortunately included probably 30 minutes of timer doze time. 

But this morning, I plowed through it. The whole time thinking I would never finish. SW->SE->NE->NW

SEISMS crossing FIEF was interesting to me, because I always mix up the I and E for both words. It took me a while to realize it isn‚Äôt spelled FeiF. 

If AYOEDIBIRI Shows up tomorrow, I still probably will get it wrong. 

Well constructed. For me. A good Saturday. For others, probably too easy
Today I count nine words that I encounter ONLY in nyt puzzles.  That's about average.

I just discovered crossword puzzles less than a year ago, after getting bored of another game I‚Äôd been playing for a few years, so I can‚Äôt tell if today's really was unusually easy for a Saturday, or it just happened to have the hidden theme, "mostly stuff Ed knows". I love that I learn something new from almost every puzzle‚Äîdespite all the times I‚Äôve been to Ireland, ERSE was a TIL.

Nit pick: AMIGA is a model of computer; the brand is Commodore. And they really were amazing machines for their time!

Great job even though there wasn‚Äôt necessarily a highlighted theme and no current ‚Äúpoliticians‚Äù were involved! As usual, it took me less than an hour to complete and I don‚Äôt look anything up and never have yet either. 
Thanks for the shoutout on 29 across given that I‚Äôm a Double Aquarius and Pisces!! The clue was super on point too. I‚Äôd love to see more Astrological terms in the future puzzles please! Those who aren‚Äôt familiar with the subject are legit surprised when I explain that Aquarians are AIR SIGNS rather than Water. Yes, it‚Äôd make more sense for it to be a Water sign given the name but then again there‚Äôs really 13 Constellations. Just like how we really should have 13 months in a year with each month being 28 days long too. Okay I‚Äôll stop with my ‚ÄúS*it Made Up By Man‚Äù rant now lol! 
Anyways, thanks again and I hope my fellow NYTers are having a Spectacular Saturday!
Namaste!!
Nice puzzle but can we get a little more challenge on Saturday?
I LOVE the Pride flag hint!
31D was my favorite clue in this puzzle. I had a good laugh when I figured it out.
A nice little boost of confidence since it was the first Saturday I have solved without any hints, auto check, or peeking  in a very long time :)
Mochi should be handed out on all occasions!
Even Ms. Edebiri would be embarrassed to know her name has come up three days in a row.
Egad! Back in the latter 80's I chose Amiga over Atari when comparing computers. I still have an Amiga (AmigaOne X5000) but didn't even think of that as I filled in TARI after the A I had at 44D!

Once again my lack of cultural knowledge slowed me down, is what I want to say, but actually it was the misdirects mostly.

This took me around 50 minutes, but it was mostly enjoyable. I had to run the alphabet on mochi/mood to get the M, but other than that, I had to use my detective skills most of the time. (Is that why they are called clues?)

My deerstalker is off to those who found this fast or even too fast.

Bonked myself big time by filling BIG READER for 1A instead of EGGHEADED. Took me a while to realize that was the thing holding me back in the upper half - that and ERSE, which I mixed up with EIRE. I felt a bit silly once I finally got them right. But that is why I love crosswords; they‚Äôre like yoga for the brain! The stretching is the point!

I live spitting distance from Detroit's Mariner's Church, the "musty old hall," where the bell "rang twenty-nine times/for each man on the Edmund Fitzgerald." Can I see it from my dining room window? Not quite--the RenCen gets in the way.

But the ship sank much further north, off Whitefish Point, at the eastern end of the Upper Peninsula. It's one of my favorite spots in Michigan--beautiful and desolate. In recent years, It's starting to become more "touristy," between ship-wreck junkies and bird-watchers; so try to catch it on an off day.  The spectacular Tahquamenon Falls is about 25 mi. away, also worth a visit. We try to get up there at least once a year
Wow, blatant mistake by the Times. Even Derek Zoolander knows 9D is spelled "DAIYE SPA"

I think today‚Äôs puzzle wins the award for most answers I‚Äôve never heard of, never heard used in the way they are referenced or still don‚Äôt understand even after I‚Äôve solved them. Not sure if that‚Äôs a compliment or a criticism. :)
Use 26A in a sentance please (actually, I just want to see if it looks as stupid as it sounds).

@Mr Dave

Yes. But the NYT Games editors use dictionary.com, which is crowdsourced, instead of a real lexicographical reference work, such as the OED or MW. Dictionary.com (and a host of other online versions of otherwise reputable dictionaries) has never met a trendy neologism or popularized misspelling it didn‚Äôt like.

P.S. I say this as someone who regularly  (and not always on purpose) lumps together words that should be hyphenated or separates words that should be one. I just bemoan the dearth of publications I can rely on to employ rigorous editing to check my worst spelling instincts‚Ä¶
No hyphen here either: https://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/fortunetelling

@Sam Lyons

The clues fall into line as per the NYT Style Book, not related to Harry.  Where the Style Book gets its information is another issue. Most likely, just editorial decision.

I wouldn't rely on the Collins for ANYthing except wrapping fish waste.  
M-W is barely better.  
New Oxford American for me.

@Mean Old Lady

It always annoys me when people think the dictionary‚Äîwhichever one‚Äîis wrong. 

It means they want the language to remain fossilized the way they learned it. 

I don‚Äôt like the fact that many dictionaries allow‚Äîeven prefer‚Äî‚Äúyay big‚Äù to ‚Äúyea big,‚Äù including, apparently, the OED. To me, this is an example of misuse become so common that it becomes normalized. 

But it is the way it is. Always has been; always will be. It‚Äôs why Dickens sounds old-fashioned, Shakespeare sounds like practically a different language, and Beowulf IS a different language. 

Dictionaries catalog a language as it is, not the way it once was, or as it ‚Äúshould be‚Äù.

When I see something that surprises me in a dictionary, I don‚Äôt say ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt like this dictionary.‚Äù I say ‚ÄúWow, I didn‚Äôt realize that word/usage/spelling is now accepted.‚Äù

@Sam Lyons
Ezersky has cited MW and NOAD as his his primary sources for the bee numerous times, and I can‚Äôt recall him ever mentioning dictionary.com.

@Steve L

That‚Äôs one of the things I like about the American Heritage Dictionary. They have a usage panel of linguists, writers and editors that they consult on non-standard usage. It might hypothetically say ‚Äú75% of the members of our usage panel object to ‚Äòyay big.‚Äô In 2015, 90% objected to that usage.‚Äù It gives you a good idea of how the language is evolving while also giving you some backup if you want to be a purist about it.

@Eric Hougland

Yeah, I loved that feature of the American Heritage, too.

Aside:
 I was exposed to quite a bit of Japanese culture when living in Hawaii (even our DoD schools were run on thee Japanese model) and it was broadening.    My English teacher, Miss Nakagi, had survived the Hilo typhoon and flooding as a young girl along with her father and grandmother; her mother and two small brothers all perished.  She showed some of us female students a photo of her husband-to-be; it was an arranged marriage...in 1960.  
Living in the Territory of Hawaii was interesting!  It was called a "melting pot" and Lei Day (May Day) celebrated the many cultures represented in the population... most or all of whom had preserved their cultural heritages.  So much for the melting pot...   As 'Haoles' we were a minority.  That was pretty interesting, too.

Example: I tell my college students that electronic devices have no place in our classroom.  They need to purchase a "real" book (not an e-book) and come to class with the book and paper and something to write with.

And now an earworm:

"The legend lives on from the Chippewa on down
Of the big lake they call Gitche Gumee
SUPERIOR, they said, never gives up her dead
When the gales of November come early."
@Mean Old Lady, I can confirm that my third grade students still make those fortune tellers!

@The X-Phile--I was a Marine aboard the carrier Midway 75-77. I must have heard that song a hundred times when it came out. When we were passing through the storied Malacca Strait narrows I found it kind of disturbing. Good thing Gord's voice was so soothing....

I loved that guy!

@Katie

Yeah, me, too.  I've loved "The Wreck of the Edmund Fitzgerald" from the very first time I heard it.

There's something just so *nautical* about it.  One can feel the  rhythm of the waves in the lyrics, which are utterly haunting.

"At seven p.m. a main hatchway caved in, he said 'Fellows, it's been good to know ya'".

Since then I don't know how many great books were published about it.  One mentions  the ship had long tunnels in it, to get to various parts of the ship without going on deck.  

In port, you could see down a tunnel from one end of the ship to the other.  But during a storm the ship would flex so much that was no longer possible.

Lake Superior is absolutely beautiful.  But it can also be terrifying.
@M&M I was thinking ATARI but that didn't quite fit. Also tried hard to remember the ALTAIR but couldn't get that one until I looked it up just now...and realized that is too long for the space.

@Jane Wheelaghan

In case you were wondering, HAIL MARY refers to a certain play in American football. When a game is in the final seconds, if the trailing team has possession and could win with a touchdown, but is far from the goal line, a HAIL MARY pass is a long, high-risk throw to the end zone.  All the receivers run down that way, and hopefully someone is lucky enough to catch it. Of course, the other team has an equal chance to catch it, and sometimes, no one catches it. 

If the offense scores and wins, it‚Äôs thrilling for their fans. But usually it doesn‚Äôt work. So why do they run the play?  Generally, it‚Äôs the only option from that distance. 

You could guess why it‚Äôs called that!

That‚Äôs probably more about HAIL MARY passes than you wanted to know!
